content.webTitle: World Cup watch ... One day to go

fields.headline: World Cup watch ... One day to go
fields.bodyText: Injured Iniesta to fly to South Africa Andrés Iniesta will go to the World Cup after scans suggested the injury to his right thigh suffered in Tuesday's 6-0 win over Poland is not as serious as first feared. The Spanish federation said yesterday that an MRI revealed swelling but it "does not appear to be a tear". Spain did not say when the midfielder would be fit to play, with their first game looming on Wednesday against Switzerland. Iniesta has had problems with the same thigh muscle for the past year. South Africa A Portuguese photographer was held up at gunpoint early yesterday at a World Cup hotel. Antonio Simoes said he woke around 4am as two men entered his room at the Nutbush Boma Lodge outside Magaliesburg, 75 miles northwest of Johannesburg. "One of the guys pointed a hand gun at my head, and then they took all my gear – cameras, lenses, laptop," said Simoes, who works for the Portuguese daily O Jogo. Chile The World Cup injury curse has spread to the referees and Chile's Pablo Pozo Quinteros. The whole Chilean trio of match officials will be replaced for their first match between Algeria and Slovenia on 13 June. Guatemalan referee Carlos Alberto Batres will take over along with his assistants Leonel Leal of Costa Rica and Carlos Pastrana of Honduras. Australia Tim Cahill is expected to be available for Australia against Germany on Sunday after hurting his neck in a warm-up game against the USA. Harry Kewell is also back in full training after recovering from a groin strain he picked up earlier this year. Italy Marcello Lippi has rejected accusations that his Italy side are too long in the tooth to win the World Cup. The average age of the squad is 28 years, nine months but Lippi insisted: "We are not the oldest, there are a couple of teams older than us." After receiving a signed Bafana Bafana shirt, Zuma held it aloft, trophy-style, as their captain, Aaron Mokoena looked on
